properties.name: Cafe Deux Soleil
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks  2096 Commercial DriveDespite an organizational fondness for hosting Poetry Slams and (uhhh) a reggae night, Cafe Deux Soleil is a damn fine spot to grab what\'s probably the only decent breakfast for under on the Drive, or at least, in the two years since I\'ve been there. Friends of mine would attempt to bring me out to Bon\'s, but that place was also a tad too dirty for my liking, even if the retired security guard (in uniform) who serves coffee out of the goodness of his own heart necessitates at least one visit and a couple of chuckles. I\'ve heard complaints about the attitude of the staff, but damn, serving bitchy vegans for 8 hours a day sort of breeds that, don\'t you think? And who the hell are you, Rockefeller? Complaining about the help and splurging on your big 0 meal, Jesus. I only really ever ate the Tofu Scramble... All the condiments you can handle. Does it get any more "Vancouver" than that photo?

properties.name: Casa Del Popolo
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks  Part of the vast and esoteric GodSpeedYouBlack Empire, which at its zenith, threatened to swallow up the vast economic and cultural concerns in Montreal\'s Mile End (traditionally dominated by varying ethnic mafiosos), but now lurks in the shadows, subsisting off of royalty cheques and awaiting the return of droning post-rock and the subsequent cash run-off, Casa Del Popolo remains. By day a cafe serving healthy and cheap eats for bespectacled and bescarved vegetarian youngsters, at night its transformed into a veritable BFA juke-shack, hosting live music (no jam bands, thank God) and a number of DJ nights. A favourite past-time is patrolling the Books For Prisoners box for inappropriate reading material, such as the stack of Teen Sex Romp novels in there a couple of months back. Amenities include: two bathrooms, running water, a distroboto machine, pretty pictures on the walls, amiable staff, cheap coffee.

properties.name: Cinquième Péché
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks It was a fateful morning that summer day when I awoke, much earlier than usual, and went for a stroll. Passing by the restaurant, I noticed a whole mess of smoke rising up from out of the ceiling and quickly made my way up to the payphone to dial 911, to explain in very patchy French that the place was on fire. Can\'t vouch for the food, as I\'ve never eaten there, but I\'ll accept a free meal for saving the place, thank you.

properties.name: Clinton St. Baking Company & Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks 4 clinton st., new yorkI tried to convince my travelling companions to check this place out, but the wait for brunch on Saturday morning seemed a little too long, and I ended up getting an espresso across the street from some apparently Fellini-themed cafe to help stave off hunger... Is this good food? It\'s certainly raved about enough, and there was that telling line-up, but maybe I missed the profile on Food TV or something... Co-owner DeDe Lahman (photographed below) used to be an advice columnist.

properties.name: Club Lambi
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks 4465 boulevard saint laurentTropical getaway and clubhouse for Pop Montreal\'s Dan Seligman, this 300+ capacity venue unites the previously disparate Haitian ex-pat and Mile End bohemian communities. In-house DJs IVORY TEMPLE (hey, that\'s 1/2 me!) are often spotted, bickering over what song to play next and fucking with the effects on the mixer. Conveniently located atop one of North America\'s only remaining Swinger\'s Clubs. Has hosted a number of groups thus far: Annie, Islands, Sailor White, The Juan McLean, Tim Sweeney, et plus. Owner and bartender Roman is a Haitian transplant in Montreal, and during the 80s headed up a Montreal breakdancing crew that would travel to competitions throughout the region and into the US.

properties.name: Ditch Records
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks  635 Johnson St.Run by the slightly misanthropic and enigmatic JR, Ditch Records is one of the finest record stores in Canada, stocking an equal variety of used albums and new releases (spanning from your garden variety college/indie hits to classic rock to soul to punk to hip-hop to whatever else) at unexpectedly low prices.

properties.name: Hasidim Hangout
properties.description: Posted by GoldkicksThe Hasidim know how to let loose. Goyish observers may be tickled by such holidays as Purim (commemorating Esther\'s heroism in Persia) and Sukhot (when observers build a thatched-roof hut to eat in).

properties.name: La Croissanterie Figaro
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks A croissanterie complete with massive brick oven, handsome lighting and decorated in a light, art-nouveau style. The Incontournable sandwich is a highlight, as well as the engagé Outremonters, arguing over the issues of the day as presented in Le Devoir. The terrasse is the finest within a ten-block radius, guaranteed.

properties.name: Local 23
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks23 Bernard OuestClothing store (also sells charming, assorted bric-a-brac) that sells vintage pieces as well as . Owned by transplanted Torontonian Jessica Moss, Calgarian Jennifer Glasglow, and Genevieve Heistek (places unknown). I was in there a couple of months back and witnessed a sketchy tall Quebecois guy run off with the cash box after unconvincingly masquerading as an employee and escape on a bicycle he\'d stashed on Clark.

properties.name: Munro's Books
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks1108 Government St.Opened at some point in the early 1960s by Jim Munro and his wife, Alice (a familiar name to many, she\'s you know, always neck in neck for the title of short story Queen), it\'s a beautiful airy bookstore with a well-curated stock (a number of years ago before the onslaught, it was one of the only places in Canada to pick up McSweeney\'s titles) and seemed to have a knack for hiring pretty literature students, which must work up the old British gentlemen retirees inquiring after the most recent John Le Carre. Located on one of my favourite blocks in Victoria, right beside the smoke shop.

properties.name: Pat's Pub
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks  A little bit after moving to Vancouver (my tenure was rather brief) I was passed the reigns to booking Pat\'s Pub by the very personable and wonderful Mr. Chris Frey (he formerly of Radio Berlin, currently of The Book Of Lists), and spent the rest of the couple of months I did it baffled at how supportive people seemed of most of the shows that were put on, coming out just for the sake of seeing some music, and how immensely fun it was. It also helped that Pat\'s closed just after 12, leaving me time to go out afterwards and imbibe in a place where I had a little less responsibility. I saw many sweet bands before, during and after working here, including Radio Berlin, JWAB/Black Mountain (on my b-day!), The Battles, Orphan, Channels 3+4 (when Jesse dosed the crowd with a bunch of liquid THC he had somehow "come across" a day or so earlier), and uhh, countless other ones. Anyways, it was a spectacular time, and I trust that it\'s still the kick-ass place it was when Hana was booking it, too. I always thought that mural of Elvis on the stage-wall looked suspiciously like Steve Bays, in the Marnik days of HHH.

properties.name: Pharmacie Esperanza
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks   5490 St. LaurentYoungster cafe that serves vegetarian food, coffee, organic teas and juices and has a small selection of booze available. Pastries and cakes provided by local cake shop Coco Rico, if memory serves correctly. The decor hints at fripperies and thread-worn Victoriana (if not many of the customers, ba-doom-shhhhhhh), there\'s a selection of older New Yorkers available (that\'s choice) and some Scrabble boards. The soundtrack changes with the whims of the employees, last week I think I heard half of a Red Krayola album followed by a collection of Prince singles, which isn\'t necessarily a bad thing at all. Smoking section in the back, equipped with Distroboto. It\'s also where they hang the art, strangely.

properties.name: Pop Montreal International Music Festival
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks  110 ave du Mont Royal OuestFrom their "fortress perch", like ospreys, the guardians of both Montreal\'s lackluster and thriving independent music scenes toil day and night to ensure that every fall, the world is presented with like, one real huge party.

properties.name: Sala Rossa
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks 4848 St. Laurent BoulevardAnother arm of the GodSpeedYouBlack Empire, operating clandestinely above a Spanish Social Club and Resto known, appropriately enough, as Sala Rosa (that\'s one "s", bub), this 300+ capacity room has long been a mainstay for larger indie touring acts and local groups alike. Moody atmosphere, great sightlines and a decent soundsystem. Occasionally hosts "The Goods": a monthly night of afro, soul and so forth riddims from Mirror columnist Scott C and Andy Williams that creates easily one of the best dancefloors you\'ll have in Montreal.

properties.name: Social Club
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks 180 St. ViateurBasically, St. Viateur coffee drinkers align themselves with one of two establishments... Further to the East, and well-recovered from a 2005 fire that cost them more than a couple of months of business, lies Cafe Olympico. While their pool table and higher ceilings are tempting indeed, knowledgeable layabouts have long been on to the hidden delights of Club Social. Unrefined sugar, prices a quarter cheaper, legal gambling for members, a selection of all of Montreal\'s daily newspapers (and the Globe & Mail!), weekly movie nights, a superior terrasse (avec shading tree!) and an enforced sense of community that comes from the round-table format are the key components ensuring loyalty from the primarily Anglophone, Francophone, and Italian customer base. Others may try to convince visitors and other naive people of the many pleasures to be had at Romelo on Ave du Parc, but a deep and abiding suspicion of that place and its inhabitants unites Olympico and Social customers alike.

properties.name: The Gateway To Hell
properties.description: Posted by GoldkicksWawa, ONHell may be Sartrean (other people) or Ahrendtian (banal), but whatever your personal conception of it may be, save a little thought for the small town of Wawa, situated somewhere between Winnipeg and Toronto, and basically the last gas stop for an obscene amount of kilometres heading east. This fact combined with a gas station that refuses to offer 24 hour service means that Wawa has a thriving little hotel industry, which gives me cause to speculate that the owner of the gas station might be the mayor and the judge and the sherrif and whatever else, just like Dan Aykroyd\'s creepy character in "Nothing But Trouble." (Which, incidentally, also featured a very young Tupac as a member of Digital Underground (you know, from "Humpty Hump" and "Sex Packets"). There are also two giant geese statues in the town. Deliverance jokes at the expense of rural folk are more than a little passe, but this is one of a very few places that I\'ve been to (and I grew up in northern BC, for Christ\'s sake) that actually gives me a foreboding sense of doom and creepiness. I\'ve heard tales about Wawa being a major curse for hitch-hikers, who are dropped off and stranded there at an above-average rate. Shayne Wardrop is said to host a spectacular curling bonspiel every spring, though.

properties.name: The Green Room
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks  5386 St. Laurent BoulevardThough Gazette columnist T\'cha Dunlevy\'s new bar Boa, located right across the street, is quickly capturing the hearts and minds of the over 30 year old set, the Green Room has firmly established itself as the weekday watering hole and weekend booze-palace for Mile End youngsters and their adoring fans. Thankfully not the exclusive Anglophone haunt it once used to be, it\'s a weekend hotspot for even the off-Plateau types. With a cast of DJs including Thomas Sontag (yep, lil\' bro of Tiga (forever resentful?), Andrew Rose (host of the Pop Montreal Popcast and Myspace Prophet), the incomparable John Lee, Ivory Temple (that\'s myself and Guillaume Decouflet, yep) Marie-Helene, Insomniak, and members of the Kidnapper Films crew, the music runs the gamut from your standard car-commercial indie fare to kraut rock to electro to hip-hop to Guillaume\'s patented baile-funk mixdowns. Get your leg up. Occasionally hosting live bands who\'re not yet recognized enough to draw in the bigger room upstairs (The Diableros played a lil\' while back, one assumes the next time it\'ll be a bigger venue), all of that\'s taken care of by the lovely folks at Greenland Productions.

properties.name: Vinyl Lounge
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks2109 de bleuryFormerly Luba, Vinyl Lounge is now under the more than friendly ownership of two Ottawa immigrants. With far more room in the bathrooms than on the dancefloor (what are those chairs in there for? I foresee disaster!), Vinyl might not be your first choice for clubbing fun, but the relatively unpretentious, mixed atmosphere is conducive to bumping and grinding on the dancefloor. The weekend crowd tends to veer towards the klaxxon sniffing, so if semi-ironic hip-hop and Vice magazine fashionistas ain\'t your cup of tea, it might end up a bit aggravating. Nonetheless, Youth Culture as it is in 2006 stands finely represented... DJs and crews: Peer Pressure, Kops Krew, Sean Kosa, Scott Roberts, Emmanuelle, John Lee, et plus.

properties.name: Zoobizarre
properties.description: Posted by Goldkicks 6388 St. HubertCavernous venue and club run by the Alex duo (Alex Lemieux and Alex Auche, programmers of last year\'s MEG Festival) that hosts packed-to-the-gills nights like Lemieux\'s Flaky Disco, Ghislain Poirier\'s Bounce Le Gros, and the Sons of Warsaw night... Italo-Disco, hip-hop, dancehall, electro, left-fieldisms and so forth. Predominantly Francophone and fun-loving crowd. WARNING: You may hear Bangkok Impact songs more than once a night here... Conveniently located close to Au Petit Buck, famed north Montreal karoake bar and site of more than a few karoake-inspired brawls...
